Room and board
rates to go up
By ALAN HIRSCH
Dormitory room and board
rates will be increased next year
by more than 15 percent over the
1973-1974 rate, Dean of
Students Robert Fitzpatrick
announced yesterday.
17-18%
Board rates will rise 17-18
percent and all University
housing, including Dorms and
University-owned apartments will
increase in cost by 13 percent
Fitzpatrick cited inflationary
factors such as increases in the
cost of fuel, food, and labor as
the primary reasons for the room
and board hikes.
Estimates
The increases were formulated,
Fitzpatrick said, "based on
estimates of a 50 percent rise in
fuel oil Cost, 10 percent jump in
electric rates and 15 percent hike
in service maintenance contracts."
The cost of a double room in the
dorms for next year will rise $80,
from $645 to $725, and the
single room's rate will jump
S125, from $750 to $825.
The fifteen meal food plan

next year. which will entitle a
student to any fifteen meals in a
week, will rise in price
$125, from S710 to $835, and
the twenty meal plan, which
replaces this year's twenty-one
meal plan, will rise $140, from
$785 to $925. In the dorms next
year there will only be two meals
on Sundays, dinner and an
extended brunch, instead of
three.
Idea Rejected
Fitzpatrick said that he
rejected the idea of making the
cost of the dorm food plans
variable over the course of the
upcoming year. since parents and
students must plan their budgets
for the entire year at the
beginning of the academic year.
Levering
Prices in Levering Hall will be
determined and reviewed on a
quarterly basis. Fitzpatrick
revealed.
He also explained that thenew
room and board rates will be
used in computing next year's
financial aid packages

In a meeting last night, the
Spring Fair Board finalized plans
for Hopkins' annual three-day
festival, April 26-28.
"3400 On Stage" will cover
the entire campus, from the gym
to Garland Hall, with exhibits,
amusement rides, puppet shows
and refreshment booths.
The Fair will officially begin
Friday of that weekend, with the
ascension of 2000 helium-filled
balloons in front of Homewood
House.
Step Right Up!
"The Midway", a string of

Chaplain's Flea Market" with

activities. In addition, 200 arts

the better exhibits will be given
the better display locations.

MaryPIRG, the Indo-China Peace
Campaign, and the National
Organization for Reform of
Marijuana Laws will also be
presenting exhibits at the Spring
Fair.
Other "3400" events include a
roving presentation of "The
Wizard of Oz", a kite-flying
contest sponsored by the Union
Governing Board, a square dance,
and a variety of concerts.
To accommodate the large
number of families expected to
attend the Fair will sponsor a
Kiddies' Theater, puppet show,
pony and bumper car rides, and
the Emmett Kelly Jr. Circus.
Four information booths will
be equipped with television sets

Engineering Club that will
continuously flash schedules of
events and emergency notices. A
display of fireworks will signal

the end of the Fair Sunday
evening.

over chairmanship of the Fair
expressed optimism. "We're in
the final stretch now. We've got.
lots of elaborate plans. Now we
just have to make them work."
Although some profit-making

"This Fair is on such a grand

for us to make a profit. We'll be
lucky to break even."

The revelations concerning the 200 successful top
applicants for next year's freshman class made this week by
Admissions Director John R. Riina contain some favorable
news for the Homewood undergraduate. For the fist time in
a long while, it appears that there is a group of applicants to
Hopkins that is not made up primarily of pre-med or natural
science students. At an institution that has seemingly always
shown a bias in one of those directions, any trend towards
diversification is to be encouraged.
True, the mean SAT scores of the 200 best qualified
candidates for admission showed only 5.5 point and 8 point
increases in verbal and math respectively, but for Hopkins the
scores of 685 and 721 are high enough to be encouraging.
What the admissions office must do now is to attempt to
diversify the interests and raise the average board scores of all
the applicants they accept, not just the top 200.
Although Riina's office has certainly done an acceptable
job in the selection of the "200 club" as it will undoubtedly
come to be known, the more crucial work still remains to be
done. Since, as Riina admits, his office cannot hope to enroll
more than 40 percent of these students. the make-up of next
year's freshman class will really be determined by the group
of applicants accepted for admission on the normal schedule
of the admissions department. Those decisions due to be
mailed early next month are far more important than the
total yield from the 200 club.
What the admissions office must do now is make a
coordinated effort to admit a highly qualified class that is
equally representative of all academic interests. Anything else
would be more of the same, something Hopkins can do
without.

I think my fellow students

Potential that Hopkins has, the

the Student Council's selections

the Committee on

two schools, I've been a
representative to the student
council and this year I'm
president of the Senior Class.

as student assistant to the Dean,
or student ombudsman. I've
worked with both Deans,
chairmen of the departments,
with members of the Board of

Bene t ta Mansfield: I'm a

position encompasses. I don't

views in that body. I'm running

job, and I'm sincerely interested

feel that I could serve my

representation on the Board for
the Med school, and I think the
vieWs of the undergraduates

Board.

Understand the position,
opinions, and feelings of the
undergraduate at Johns

large part, evidenced by the
presence of the four Young

devote more time to trying to
realize to what, in fact, the
position of an Undergraduate

Trends throughout the country,

new alternatives, must be

The revelations concerning the 200 successful top
applicants for next year's freshman class made this week by
Admissions Director John R. Riina contain some favorable
news for the Homewood undergraduate. For the fist time in

diversify the interests and raise the average board scores of all
the applicants they accept, not just the top 200.

done. Since, as Riina admits, his office cannot hope to enroll

year's freshman class will really be determined by the group
of applicants accepted for admission on the normal schedule
of the admissions department. Those decisions due to be
mailed early next month are far more important than the
total yield from the 200 club.
What the admissions office must do now is make a
coordinated effort to admit a highly qualified class that is
equally representative of all academic interests. Anything else
would be more of the same, something Hopkins can do
without.

Three Young Trustees candidates air views
Question: What do you feel
are your strongest qualifications
for the position on the Board
and why do you want to be a
member of the Board as a
Young Trustee?
John McGilliam: i base my
qualifications mainly on my
familiarity of Hopkins but most
important, my platform which I
think would be most
advantageous to Hopkins.
Shep Hoffman: A
committment to improving the
quality of undergraduate
education at Hopkins a belief
that Hopkins is a good
university that can be made
better, both for its students and
faculty, and a strong feeling
that Johns Hopkins has a role
to play both for its own
community and for Baltimore
city, motivates me to run for
Young Trustee and to work for
all of ttese things in that
position. The position of Young
Trustee offers the Board
of Trustees : the opportunity
to stay abreast of current
student's thinking with regards
to all Hopkins affairs. From the
past four yours I've tried to
work with students, faculty,
and adminisstration to do what
I thought was right in helping
to improve education and life in
general at Johns Hopkins. I
have a great respect for the
quality of education at Johns
Hopkins but I quite realize that
the University doesn't live up to
what might be a much greater
potential. And
guess in all
honesty I feel my work for four
years along with a very real
desire -to help direct the
University in the future towards
things which I think, and which
I think my fellow students
think are important, moves me
to run for the position of
Young Trustee. In terms of
qualifications for the positions
the typical thing to do is to set
up a nice list of things which
one has done over the past four
years and point to these as

qualifications. In my freshman
year, a desire to participate in
the Hopkins community and
the Baltimore city community
motivated my participation in
various campus and non-campus
activities. During Freshman
year, as a member of the
Dormitory Student Residents
Council I tried to work to
improve life for freshmen in the
Dormitories. In addition, I
became involved in the
Chaplain's office. My service
with the Chaplain's office really
heightened my awareness of the
Potential that Hopkins has, the
entire university community,
for serving the city of
Baltimore. My campus activities
include such things as helping
to write the 1973-1974
University Catalogue, serving on
the Student Council's selections
committee during my
sophomore year. being an
undergraduate student rep to
the Student Conduct Code
Committee, coordinating and
directing the first TEVAL at
Hopkins, which is still
continuing. I've been an
undergraduate representative to
the Committee on
Undergraduate tudies. Last
summer. I was a student rep to
the joint Goucher Hopkins
Committee on the future of the
two schools, I've been a
representative to the student
council and this year I'm
president of the Senior Class.
Last and by no means least, and
perhaps the most important
thing to me, has been my role
as student assistant to the Dean,
or student ombudsman. I've
worked with both Deans,
chairmen of the departments,
with members of the Board of
Trustees and with various other
faculty members.
Bene t ta Mansfield: I'm a
student and I'm an active
student. But I really don't feel
that there's any special
qualification that makes you a
good Young Trustee. I've been

very active both inside school
and off the campus. But having
spoken to the present young
Trustees, I Oink the
undergraduate body here knows
very little about what the
position encompasses. I don't
think that serving on the
Student Council or working on
student organizations
necessarily qualifies one for
Trustee. When I went in front
of the Board of Trustees last
year, on behalf of the Student
Council, I felt that they were
very interested and receptive to
the problems of Homewood. I
think I could represent our
views in that body. I'm running
because I sincerely want the
job, and I'm sincerely interested
in the future of the school. I
feel that I could serve my
constitutents,• and by my
constituents I mean .the
undergraduates of Hopkins. I
think there's an awful lot of
representation on the Board for
the Med school, and I think the
vieWs of the undergraduates
have to be conveyed to the
Board.
Question: What programs or
in which areas of University
affairs would you like to see the
Board devote its attention to in
its upcoming sessions?
Shep Hoffman: I believe the
trustees have expressed a very
sincere interest in trying to
Understand the position,
opinions, and feelings of the
undergraduate at Johns
Hopkins. This is certainly, in
large part, evidenced by the
presence of the four Young
Trustees on the Board of
Trustees In this regard, I would
generally like to see the Board
devote more time to trying to
realize to what, in fact, the
position of an Undergraduate
student at Johns Hopkins is.
Specifically, I Would direct
myself to a few proposals.
Trends throughout the country,
not just in University tuition,
but in all finances, have shown

us all that everything is only
going to cost more. At Hopkins
tuition is going up. It's going to
continue to go up. I feel very
strongly that some alternative,
new alternatives, must be
sought t pass on the increased
costs of education to the
students, both undergraduate
and gi-aduate. I feel very
strongly that we insure that no
student is turned away from
Hopkins for financial reasons. I
believe, in addition, that it is
certainly within the Board's
charge to urge the office of
admissions, to seek out a more
diverse body for admission. The
quality and diversity of the
Hopkins faculty is not in tune
with the quality and diversity
of its students. Finally, it is
important, even vital, that we
raise funds to sustain the
University. In addition to
strengthening the University's
endowment, I would like to see
the Board strengthen the
quality of education at
Hopkins.
Benetta Mansfield: First of
all, I want to beg the question a
little. I can remember the
candidates running and making
a lot of promises. I don't
believe a candidate for Young
Trustee can make promises. I
think that one person on a
board of 50 Trustees has very
little power to get a program
across or to get anything
through the Board. The biggest
fault I see in electing young
trustees is that we elect them
and then we never hear from
them again. I think that it's
really important that a Young
Trustee write articles for the
News-Letter, as to what's going
on with the Board of Trustees,
to come back the day before
the Trustee meeting and spend
the entire day on campus
talking to students and seeing
how they feel, to keep in
contact with student
organizations and seeing what
they're doing. I see that as my

most important function on the
Board of Trustees, to keep in
contact with the
undergraduates. As to what I'd
like to see the Board deal with,
I think the school has many
problems. I would hope that
the Board will deal with the
problems that the library is
encountering, that is
overcrowding, low finances, and
a deficient collection. Also I
would urge the Board to deal
with the problem of housing,
either by building more dorms
or by buying up more housing
,in Homewood. The freshmen
and the "upperclassmen are
frantic each spring looking for
housing in a tight housing
situation. I think that the
admissions policy of the school
needs some revision. I,
understand that the school
never intends to have an
equalization of men and
women. I think this, is very
wrong. I don't advocate a
quota, however I think that
admissions standards should be
fair to everyone. I think it's
very important to recruit and
increase the applicant pool in
every subject in the school. I
want to stress again how
important I think it is for a
Young Trustee to be
responsible to keep the
undergraduates informed about
what's going on. Both
candidates who have announced
[their, candidacy] for the
student council presidency have
stressed the need to improve
academics here. It would be to
the benefit of any young
Trustee to keep informed of
what the undergraduates want
and need, and in turn to try to
keep the Board informed of
what is going on. The Board of
Trustees was shocked at some
of the statistics of this school.
They really might be interested
they knew more.
